column2: 'Every single thing's crooked,' Alice thought to herself, 'and she's all over pins!--may I put your shawl straight for you?' she added aloud.
column3: 'Every single thing's crooked,' Alice thought to herself, 'and she's all over pins!--may I put your shawl straight for you?' she added aloud.

column2: 'I don't know what's the matter with it!' the Queen said, in a melancholy voice.
column3: 'I don't know what's the matter with it!' the Queen said, in a melancholy voice.

column2: 'The brush has got entangled in it!' the Queen said with a sigh.
column3: 'The brush has got entangled in it!' the Queen said with a sigh.

column2: Alice carefully released the brush, and did her best to get the hair into order.
column3: Alice carefully released the brush, and did her best to get the hair into order.

column2: 'Come, you look rather better now!' she said, after altering most of the pins.
column3: 'Come, you look rather better now!' she said, after altering most of the pins.

column2: 'Twopence a week, and jam every other day.'
column3: 'Twopence a week, and jam every other day.'

column2: 'It's very good jam,' said the Queen.
column3: 'It's very good jam,' said the Queen.

column2: 'Well, I don't want any TO-DAY, at any rate.'
column3: 'Well, I don't want any TO DAY, at any rate.'

column2: 'It MUST come sometimes to "jam to-day,"' Alice objected.
column3: 'It MUST come sometimes to "jam to day,"' Alice objected.

column2: 'I don't understand you,' said Alice. 'It's dreadfully confusing!'
column3: 'I don't understand you,' said Alice. 'It's dreadfully confusing!'

column2: 'That's the effect of living backwards,' the Queen said kindly: 'it always makes one a little giddy at first--'
column3: 'That's the effect of living backwards,' the Queen said kindly: 'it always makes one a little giddy at first-'

column2: 'I can't remember things before they happen.'
column3: 'I can't remember things before they happen.'

column2: 'It's a poor sort of memory that only works backwards,' the Queen remarked.
column3: 'It's a poor sort of memory that only works backwards,' the Queen remarked.

column2: 'What sort of things do YOU remember best?' Alice ventured to ask.
column3: 'What sort of things do YOU remember best?' Alice ventured to ask.

column2: 'Suppose he never commits the crime?' said Alice.
column3: 'Suppose he never commits the crime?' said Alice.

column2: Alice felt there was no denying THAT. 'Of course it would be all the better,' she said: 'but it wouldn't be all the better his being punished.'
column3: Alice felt there was no denying THAT. 'Of course it would be all the better,' she said: 'but it wouldn't be all the better his being punished.'

column2: 'Only for faults,' said Alice.
column3: 'Only for faults,' said Alice.

column2: 'Yes, but then I HAD done the things I was punished for,' said Alice: 'that makes all the difference.'
column3: 'Yes, but then I HAD done the things I was punished for,' said Alice: 'that makes all the difference.'

column2: 'But if you HADN'T done them,' the Queen said, 'that would have been better still; better, and better, and better!' Her voice went higher with each 'better,' till it got quite to a squeak at last.
column3: 'But if you HADN'T done them,' the Queen said, 'that would have been better still; better, and better, and better!' Her voice went higher with each 'better,' till it got quite to a squeak at last.

column2: Alice was just beginning to say 'There's a mistake somewhere--,' when the Queen began screaming so loud that she had to leave the sentence unfinished.
column3: Alice was just beginning to say 'There's a mistake somewhere-,' when the Queen began screaming so loud that she had to leave the sentence unfinished.

column2: 'What IS the matter?' she said, as soon as there was a chance of making herself heard.
column3: 'What IS the matter?' she said, as soon as there was a chance of making herself heard.

column2: 'Have you pricked your finger?'
column3: 'Have you pricked your finger?'

column2: 'That accounts for the bleeding, you see,' she said to Alice with a smile.
column3: 'That accounts for the bleeding, you see,' she said to Alice with a smile.

column2: 'But why don't you scream now?' Alice asked, holding her hands ready to put over her ears again.
column3: 'But why don't you scream now?' Alice asked, holding her hands ready to put over her ears again.

column2: 'Why, I've done all the screaming already,' said the Queen. 'What would be the good of having it all over again?'
column3: 'Why, I've done all the screaming already,' said the Queen. 'What would be the good of having it all over again?'

column2: By this time it was getting light.
column3: By this time it was getting light.

column2: 'The crow must have flown away, I think,' said Alice: 'I'm so glad it's gone.
column3: 'The crow must have flown away, I think,' said Alice: 'I'm so glad it's gone.

column2: 'Only I never can remember the rule.
column3: 'Only I never can remember the rule.

column2: 'Oh, don't go on like that!' cried the poor Queen, wringing her hands in despair.
column3: 'Oh, don't go on like that!' cried the poor Queen, wringing her hands in despair.

column2: 'Consider what a great girl you are.
column3: 'Consider what a great girl you are.

column2: Consider what o'clock it is.
column3: Consider what o'clock it is.

column2: Consider anything, only don't cry!'
column3: Consider anything, only don't cry!'

column2: Alice could not help laughing at this, even in the midst of her tears. 'Can YOU keep from crying by considering things?' she asked.
column3: Alice could not help laughing at this, even in the midst of her tears. 'Can YOU keep from crying by considering things?' she asked.

column2: Let's consider your age to begin with--how old are you?'
column3: Let's consider your age to begin with-how old are you?'

column2: 'I'm seven and a half exactly.'
column3: 'I'm seven and a half exactly.'

column2: 'I can't believe THAT!' said Alice.
column3: 'I can't believe THAT!' said Alice.

column2: 'Can't you?' the Queen said in a pitying tone.
column3: 'Can't you?' the Queen said in a pitying tone.

column2: Alice laughed.
column3: Alice laughed.

column2: 'I daresay you haven't had much practice,' said the Queen. 'When I was your age, I always did it for half-an-hour a day.
column3: 'I daresay you haven't had much practice,' said the Queen. 'When I was your age, I always did it for half an hour a day.

column2: Why, sometimes I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.
column3: Why, sometimes I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.

column2: There goes the shawl again!'
column3: There goes the shawl again!'

column2: The Queen spread out her arms again, and went flying after it, and this time she succeeded in catching it for herself.
column3: The Queen spread out her arms again, and went flying after it, and this time she succeeded in catching it for herself.

column2: 'Then I hope your finger is better now?' Alice said very politely, as she crossed the little brook after the Queen.
column3: 'Then I hope your finger is better now?' Alice said very politely, as she crossed the little brook after the Queen.

column2: 'Oh, much better!' cried the Queen, her voice rising to a squeak as she went on.
column3: 'Oh, much better!' cried the Queen, her voice rising to a squeak as she went on.

column2: She looked at the Queen, who seemed to have suddenly wrapped herself up in wool.
column3: She looked at the Queen, who seemed to have suddenly wrapped herself up in wool.

column2: Alice rubbed her eyes, and looked again.
column3: Alice rubbed her eyes, and looked again.

column2: She couldn't make out what had happened at all.
column3: She couldn't make out what had happened at all.

column2: And was that really--was it really a SHEEP that was sitting on the other side of the counter?
column3: And was that really-was it really a SHEEP that was sitting on the other side of the counter?

column2: 'What is it you want to buy?' the Sheep said at last, looking up for a moment from her knitting.
column3: 'What is it you want to buy?' the Sheep said at last, looking up for a moment from her knitting.

column2: 'I don't QUITE know yet,' Alice said, very gently.
column3: 'I don't QUITE know yet,' Alice said, very gently.

column2: 'I should like to look all round me first, if I might.'
column3: 'I should like to look all round me first, if I might.'

column2: 'And this one is the most provoking of all--but I'll tell you what--' she added, as a sudden thought struck her, 'I'll follow it up to the very top shelf of all.
column3: 'And this one is the most provoking of all-but I'll tell you what-' she added, as a sudden thought struck her, 'I'll follow it up to the very top shelf of all.

column2: It'll puzzle it to go through the ceiling, I expect!'
column3: It'll puzzle it to go through the ceiling, I expect!'

column2: 'Are you a child or a teetotum?' the Sheep said, as she took up another pair of needles.
column3: 'Are you a child or a teetotum?' the Sheep said, as she took up another pair of needles.

column2: Feather!' the Sheep cried again, taking more needles.
column3: Feather!' the Sheep cried again, taking more needles.

column2: 'You'll be catching a crab directly.'
column3: 'You'll be catching a crab directly.'

column2: 'A dear little crab!' thought Alice. 'I should like that.'
column3: 'A dear little crab!' thought Alice. 'I should like that.'

column2: 'Didn't you hear me say "Feather"?' the Sheep cried angrily, taking up quite a bunch of needles.
column3: 'Didn't you hear me say "Feather"?' the Sheep cried angrily, taking up quite a bunch of needles.

column2: 'WHY do you say "feather" so often?' Alice asked at last, rather vexed. 'I'm not a bird!'
column3: 'WHY do you say "feather" so often?' Alice asked at last, rather vexed. 'I'm not a bird!'

column2: 'There really are--and SUCH beauties!'
column3: 'There really are-and SUCH beauties!'

column2: 'No, but I meant--please, may we wait and pick some?' Alice pleaded.
column3: 'No, but I meant-please, may we wait and pick some?' Alice pleaded.

column2: 'If you don't mind stopping the boat for a minute.'
column3: 'If you don't mind stopping the boat for a minute.'

column2: 'I only hope the boat won't tipple over!' she said to herself.
column3: 'I only hope the boat won't tipple over!' she said to herself.

column2: Only I couldn't quite reach it.' 'And it certainly DID seem a little provoking ('almost as if it happened on purpose,' she thought) that, though she managed to pick plenty of beautiful rushes as the boat glided by, there was always a more lovely one that she couldn't reach.

column2: However, she wasn't hurt, and was soon up again: the Sheep went on with her knitting all the while, just as if nothing had happened.
column3: However, she wasn't hurt, and was soon up again: the Sheep went on with her knitting all the while, just as if nothing had happened.

column2: 'That was a nice crab you caught!' she remarked, as Alice got back into her place, very much relieved to find herself still in the boat.
column3: 'That was a nice crab you caught!' she remarked, as Alice got back into her place, very much relieved to find herself still in the boat.

column2: I didn't see it,' Said Alice, peeping cautiously over the side of the boat into the dark water.
column3: I didn't see it,' Said Alice, peeping cautiously over the side of the boat into the dark water.

column2: 'Are there many crabs here?' said Alice.
column3: 'Are there many crabs here?' said Alice.

column2: 'Crabs, and all sorts of things,' said the Sheep: 'plenty of choice, only make up your mind.
column3: 'Crabs, and all sorts of things,' said the Sheep: 'plenty of choice, only make up your mind.

column2: 'I should like to buy an egg, please,' she said timidly.
column3: 'I should like to buy an egg, please,' she said timidly.

column2: 'How do you sell them?'
column3: 'How do you sell them?'

column2: 'Fivepence farthing for one--Twopence for two,' the Sheep replied.
column3: 'Fivepence farthing for one-Twopence for two,' the Sheep replied.

column2: 'Then two are cheaper than one?' Alice said in a surprised tone, taking out her purse.
column3: 'Then two are cheaper than one?' Alice said in a surprised tone, taking out her purse.

column2: 'Only you MUST eat them both, if you buy two,' said the Sheep.
column3: 'Only you MUST eat them both, if you buy two,' said the Sheep.

column2: For she thought to herself, 'They mightn't be at all nice, you know.'
column3: For she thought to herself, 'They mightn't be at all nice, you know.'

column2: The Sheep took the money, and put it away in a box: then she said 'I never put things into people's hands--that would never do--you must get it for yourself.' And so saying, she went off to the other end of the shop, and set the egg upright on a shelf.
column3: The Sheep took the money, and put it away in a box: then she said 'I never put things into people's hands-that would never do-you must get it for yourself.' And so saying, she went off to the other end of the shop, and set the egg upright on a shelf.
